page.title: 11Chew Valley Lake - Birds
page.content: Ever since the dam was completed in 1953 the 1200 acres of water have proved a magnet for birds moving through the area. This attraction is sustained by the great length of shallow, natural banks fringed by a wealth of emergent plants, (including the Country's largest reed-bed at the Herriott's Bridge end). It has gained "Site of Special Scientific Interest" status largely due to the number of ducks and grebes using the lake as a feeding area. Surface feeders are dominant although diving ducks are also frequent. The water levels are regulated so that in autumn a large expanse of mud with shallow pools is exposed. This encourages many passing migrants to land and feed before going on. This is primarily when the rarities occur and many birds usually resident in America has been seen.
